titleStmt.title: A machine-readable profile of Damscus Arabic
titleStmt.author: Stephan Procházka

sourceDesc.p: This is an original digital text

div.p: Eastern › Syro-Palestinian › Central Syrian
Urban, sedentary dialect, high-prestige variety

The dialect of the capital of Syria is regarded as a very “elegant” variety of Arabic and has a very high prestige. It is frequently used in the media and increasingly also in films. Hence, Damascus Arabic is widely understood in whole Syria, in Lebanon, and even in Jordan and Palestine.

Descriptions of the Arabic dialect of Damascus go back as far as the 18th century when the German orientalist and theologian Johann Heinrich Callenberg published his description of Damascus Arabic in Latin (Callenberg 1720-1740). Collections of texts and short grammatical notes were published at the end of the 19th and the first half of the 20th centuries (Huart 1883, Oestrup 1897 [although mostly not real Damascene dialect], Malinjoud 1924, Bergsträßer 1924, Saussey 1937-38), Cantineau 1956, Dietrich 1956) but the first comprehensive description of the dialect appeared only in the 1960s: Cowell 1964, Grotzfeld 1964, Grotzfeld 1965, Ambros 1977. Today Damascus Arabic is certainly among the Arabic dialects which are best described.
A concise grammatical sketch of the dialect is Jérôme Lentin’s “Damascus Arabic”, in EALL I, 546-555.

Barthélemy 1935-54 is still unmatched as the dictionary for Syrian Arabic, but it is mainly based on the dialect of Aleppo. Nevertheless it is extremely useful for Damascus Arabic too, as is Denizeau 1960.
Very promising is the online-dictionary titled Dictionnaire d’arabe dialectal syrien (parler de Damas) by Claude Salamé & Jérôme Lentin, although until now only the letter B has been published.
To obtain a list of dictionaries on Syrian varieties contained in our database click here.
VICAV also hosts a small digital dictionary of Damascus Arabic. It was created in connection with the Viennese textbooks and primarily serves didactic purposes. You can access it here.

The earliest evidence of a textbook in our database is Cantineau/Helbaoui's Manuel élémentaire d’arabe oriental (parler de Damas) (1953). Others to be mentioned are Ferguson's Damascus Arabic (1965), Rice's Eastern Arabic (1979) and Liddicoat's Syrian colloquial Arabic: a functional course (1999).
The Viennese textbook Lehrbuch des Syrisch-Arabischen in two volumes by Aldoukhi, Procházka and Telič is the most recent introduction to the dialect of Damascus.
To obtain a list of textbooks contained in our database click here.
Songs in Damascus Arabic are abundantly found on YouTube, look for instance for the well-known band Kulna Sawa.
To see some important publications on this variety follow this link.
A short sample text is provided here.
There is a list of linguistic features with example sentences.

titleStmt.title: A machine-readable language profile of Cairo Arabic
titleStmt.author: Charly Moerth

sourceDesc.p: This is an original digital text

div.p: Eastern › Egyptian › Central Delta
Urban, sedentary, high prestige variety

The Egyptian varieties of Arabic form a quite diversified linguistic group. They are usually subdivided into four major subgroups: the dialects of Upper Egypt, Middle Egypt, Lower Egypt and those spoken in the Oases. The dialect of the capital belongs to the northern group.

By contrast to most other varieties of vernacular Arabic, the dialect of Cairo has been reduced to writing as well. There exists quite a significant amount of literary output, in particular stage plays.

The first serious reliable descriptions of Egyptian Arabic were written in the 19th century: Wilhelm Spitta published his grammar in 1880 (which can be read online at the Internet Archive) and Vollers’ textbook in 1890 (English translation 1895, available at the Internet Archive). These were followed by Nallino (1900) (full text at the Internet Archive) and Willmore (1901) (full text at the Internet Archive).

The great bulk of publications was written after World War II. Interesting information was provided by Mitchell (1956), Tomiche (1962) and Salib (1981). Most studies followed rather traditional approaches. An exception is Wise’s transformational grammar (1975). Another very informative monography is Parkinson’s socio-linguistic study on terms of address in Egyptian Arabic (1985).

The most substantial scholarly contributions to our knowledge of the Egyptian dialects were made by the German dialectologists Behnstedt and Woidich. Most of their work was done in the 80’s and 90’s of the 20th century. Woidich’s grammar (2006) of Cairo Arabic is the so far most comprehensive in-depth study of this variety.
There exist several dictionaries for those who want to study Egyptian Arabic. The hitherto most comprehensive one is Hinds/Badawi (Arabic-English). It was published in 1986.

Socrates Spiro’s dictionary (1895) is pretty old. As there is not much available in digital form, it is still worth looking at. To access an online reading interface made up of digital images click here.
To obtain a list of Egyptian dictionaries contained in our database click here.
VICAV also provides a small digital dictionary of Cairo Arabic. It primarily serves didactic purposes. You can access it here.

For generations of learners of spoken Egyptian the course material compiled by Abdel-Massih (1978-9) was the main guidance. A more up-to-date textbook is Woidich/Heinen’s Kullu tamām! (2004). Furthermore, a graded series of textbooks by Samia Louis has to be mentioned. In these books, all the reading material is presented in the Arabic script. In addition, they come with high quality CDs.

Two German textbooks should also be highlighted: Woidich’s Ahlan wa Sahlan (2002) actually predates his Kullu tamām!. The sesond one is Ahmed’s Lehrbuch des Ägyptisch-Arabischen (1981) which unfortunately contains countless typos. Nevertheless, the texts collected there are very helpful, especially for advanced learners.
The Semitic Sound Archive provides several recordings. Follow this link.

Until the late twentieth century, the language of the Egyptian capital remained poorly documented. Meanwhile, a number of valuable descriptions have been published. The amount of publications dealing with the variety of Cairo is quite considerable. To get a more general list for Egypt click here.
VICAV provides a Sample Text of Cairo Arabic.
There is also a list of linguistic features with example sentences.

titleStmt.title: A machine-readable profile of Tunis Arabic
titleStmt.author: Ines Dallaji

sourceDesc.p: This is an original digital text

div.p: Western › Maghreb › Tunisia › Northern Tunisia
Urban, sedentary dialect, prestige variety

The Arabic dialect of Tunis as spoken today by the majority of the city’s inhabitants is a contact variety influenced by a vast population influx from all over Tunisia during the 20th century. It can be regarded as a prestige variety since speakers of other Tunisian Arabic dialects tend to shift towards it. Tunis Arabic is widely used in oral and visual media (theater, film, slogans). It is, however, rarely written except in informal letters, newspaper cartoons or advertising slogans.

The first description of the dialect of the city of Tunis can be found in the then ground-breaking study by Stumme 1896, which he published after his edition of transcribed texts (Stumme 1893). The variety spoken by the Jews of Tunis is described by Cohen 1975. The most detailed description of Tunis Arabic so far is Singer 1984, a monumental grammar of the dialect spoken in the Medina of Tunis in the early 1960s. Aspects of the syntax are investigated by Jemni 2011, important sociolinguistic studies are Gibson 1998 and Gibson 2012.
A concise grammatical sketch of the Arabic dialect of Tunis is Maik Gibson’s “Tunis Arabic” in EALL IV, 563-571.
A comprehensive up-to-date dictionary of the Arabic dialect of Tunis does not exist.
Nicolas 1911 is outdated and does not provide an appropriate transcription.
Beaussier/Lentin 2006 contains words from the whole Maghreb including data on Tunis.
Abdellatif's Dictionnaire «le Karmous» du Tunisien (2010) is a rather useful amateur glossary and can currently be downloaded from this URI.
In addition, the eight volume glossary compiled by Marçais/Guîga 1958-61 that covers the vocabulary of the village of Takrouna (ca.100 km south-east of Tunis) is very useful for Tunis Arabic, too.
A large English-Tunisian Arabic dictionary is Ben Abdelkader [et al.] 1977 which can be downloaded from this location.
To obtain a list of textbooks click here.
An example for a contemporary musician from Tunis, who is singing in the Arabic dialect of Tunis, is Amel Mathlouthi. Many of her songs can be found on the internet.
Consult our bibliography!

titleStmt.title: A machine-readable profile of Damscus Arabic
titleStmt.author: Naima Sekiati

sourceDesc.p: This is an original digital text

div.p: Western › Maghreb › Morocco
Urban (prehilalien), sedentary dialect with bedouin influence

Basically, the dialect of Salé is almost identical to that of Rabat. The varieties of both cities were strongly influenced by the impact of Bedouin infiltration mainly in the second half of the past century and the large numbers of Berbers who settled in the outskirts in the same period.

By contrast to the old dialect of Rabat (L. Brunot 1920ff.), there exist no in-depth studies of the dialect of the medina of Salé. It can be assumed that the old dialect of Salé (as is stated for Rabat) had similar basic features as Tanger and Tetouan speech. The development from an „urban“ to a „mixed rural-urban“ dialect is described by Messaoudi (2002). Recent grammatical and lexical studies on Rabat/Salé have been undertaken by Heath (2002) and Behnstedt (2011/12).

titleStmt.title: A machine-readable profile of the Arabic vernacular of al-Khaburah
titleStmt.author: Stephan Procházka

sourceDesc.p: This is an original digital text

div.p: Eastern › Arabian Peninsula › Oman
Coastal dialect characterized by a juxtaposition of both Bedouin and sedentary type features

Al-Khaburah is one of the main settlements on the Bāṭinah coast of north-eastern Oman. There are significant differences between the speech of the people living at the coast proper and the inlanders who immigrated in great numbers to the coast bringing their dialectal peculiarities with them.

Hitherto the only description of the dialect of the town and its surroundings is Brockett 1985. This book is based on fieldwork carried out in the late 1970s/early 1980s. It offers a short introduction into phonology and morphology and discusses some special syntactical features. The main part is dedicated to lexicography with a focus on agricultural terms. No texts have been published in Khaburah Arabic nor are there any sound files available.

titleStmt.title: A machine-readable language profile of Douz Arabic
titleStmt.author: Veronika Ritt-Benmimoun

sourceDesc.p: This is an original digital text

div.p: Western › Maghreb › Tunisia › Southern Tunisia
Bedouin type dialect, Sulaym group

The town of Douz is one of the greatest oases in the so-called Nifzāwa region situated south-east of the Šaṭṭ al-Ǧarīd (Chott el-Jerid). Its dialect is more or less identical to the speech of the formerly semi-nomadic Maṛāzīg tribe which numbers around 30,000 members. The Marzūgī dialect is an archaic variety of Maghrebinian Bedouin Arabic and exhibits features such as gender distinction with plural forms and internal passive voice (although of restricted use) with verbs. As a Bedouin dialect it is considered a low-variety by the speakers of sedentary dialects, e.g. of the capital Tunis, but highly appreciated by the Bedouins themselves. Only some young speakers show the tendency to accommodate to urban sedentary speech. With its rich lexicon it is the vehicle for popular poetry. As a representative of the Sulaym Group of Maghrebi Bedouin dialects it is widely understood in Libya and Eastern Algeria.

The only detailed grammatical description of the dialect of Douz is Ritt-Benmimoun's Grammatik des arabischen Beduinendialekts der Region Douz (Südtunesien). For many decades the research done by Gilbert Boris was the only reliable source for the Marzūgī dialect. Nearly all his main works were published after his death (Boris 1951a, Boris 1951b, Boris 1958). Starting in the early 2000s, Veronika Ritt-Benmimoun has begun to publish a great number of articles dedicated to the language and culture of the Maṛāzīg (see below). A voluminous monograph which includes many ethnographical texts in the dialects of the Maṛāzīg and other Bedouin tribes of the region is Ritt-Benmimoun 2011 (554 pp.). Hitherto, the Marzūgī dialect is the only Tunisian Bedouin dialect for which rich linguistic data is available.
To see a list of relevant publications in our database click here.
Boris 1958 is a very good and quite comprehensive Arabic-French dictionary (686 pp.). Additional data is found in Bin Murād 1999.
22 recordings found on the Semitic Sound Archiv. Follow this link.

sourceDesc.p: This is an original digital text

div.p: Dialect group: Maghreb, Tunisia
Urban sedentary dialect, Sāḥil group

Sousse is an important coastal city in the west of Tunisia which has been a regional trade centre for many centuries. Starting in the 1960s Sousse has developed into one of the country’s main Tourism destinations. This caused immense increase in population, especially migration from rural areas all over Tunisia, which has significantly influenced the original dialect.

A detailed study on the dialect spoken within the medina is Talmoudi 1980, a collection of texts can be found in Talmoudi 1981. An analysis of verbs of Romance origin in Tunisian dialects, including data from Sousse, is given in Talmoudi 1986. Saada 1956 is a study about the dialect of the Jews of Sousse.
Get the full list of publications on the dialect of Sousse in our database by clicking here.

titleStmt.title: A machine-readable language profile of Urfa Arabic
titleStmt.author: Stephan Procházka

sourceDesc.p: This is an original digital text

div.p: Arabia › Northern Group › Syro-Mesopotamian fringe
Bedouin dialect, minority variety

Because the official language of the region is Turkish, the Arabic dialect of the city of Urfa is a minority language. Similar varieties of Arabic are spoken in many villages and smaller towns (e.g. Harran and Akçakale) situated between Urfa and the Syrian border. Urfa Arabic is linguistically very close to the dialects of the sheep and goat breeding nomads (the so-called Shawāya) of the Syrian Steppe and arguably constitutes the northernmost variety of the Arabian Bedouin dialects. Tribal structures among the local Arabic speakers (estimated to be around 150,000) are still very strong, and the relatively strict endogamy results in a high proportion of first language speakers even among the youngest generation. Urfa Arabic is usually not written; but there are internet sites containing phrases, songs, and proverbs in vernacular Arabic written in Latin script.

Although the existence of Arabic speaking groups in the region has been known since at least the 19th century, the dialect is still poorly documented. A very short grammatical sketch is Procházka 2003, three texts with English translation are found in Procházka 2013, and a comparison of Urfa Arabic with other peripheral dialects of the region is Procházka 2006.
VICAV provides a Sample Text of this variety.

titleStmt.title: A machine-readable language profile of Baghdad Arabic
titleStmt.author: Stephan Procházka

sourceDesc.p: This is an original digital text

div.p: Eastern › Mesopotamian › Iraqi gǝlǝt (gilit)
Urban Bedouin dialect with significant sedentary substrate, high-prestige variety

The dialect of the Iraqi capital can be regarded as the prestige variety of the whole country. It is frequently used in the media and widely understood not only in Iraq, but also in the adjacent Gulf region, in Eastern Syria, and in the Iranian province of Khuzestan. The linguistic setting of Baghdad is special for its so-called “communal dialects”. The current prestige variety (described here) is actually the dialect which until fairly recently was spoken solely by the Muslim population. The Christian and Jewish (no longer in Iraq) inhabitants of Baghdad speak a very different dialect of the so-called qǝltu type, which is much closer to Northern Iraq and not influenced by Bedouin features.

The first comprehensive descriptions of the Arabic dialect of Baghdad did not appear before the 1960s. Before that only some very brief remarks (Jeannier 1888, Massignon 1912) and a few textbooks and glossaries were published, particularly Van Ess 1917 (second edition 1938, many reprints until 1989) and van Wagoner 1949, but both contain a mixture of various Iraqi dialects and cannot be regarded as dialectological descriptions. The first scholarly monographs published were Malaika 1963 and Erwin 1963, shortly followed by Blanc 1964. Blanc, who coined the term “communal dialects”, presented a rather concise but excellent description of Muslim, Christian, and Jewish Baghdadi. Abu-Haider 1991 deals with the Christian variety. Palva 2009 convincingly argues that the Bedouin (= gǝlǝt type) character of present-day Muslim Baghdadi is mainly the result of a process of bedouinization during the past 300 years. Thus, for a considerable time after the Mongol sack of Baghdad in 1258, the dialect of Baghdad had remained to be an urban Mesopotamian type dialect that has only slowly changed due to immigration from the countryside. In spite of its importance, Baghdad Arabic has not been intensively studied (compared to, e.g., Cairo or Damascus) and almost all reference works date back to the 1960s.
Our database contains a number of publications that deal with Baghdad. To get a wider picture look for reg:Iraq.
VICAV provides a Sample Text of Baghdad of Baghdad Arabic.
There is also a list of linguistic features with example sentences.

titleStmt.title: A machine-readable profile of Soukhne / Al-Sukhnah Arabic
titleStmt.author: Julia Baumgartner

sourceDesc.p: This is an original digital text

div.p: East (Mashriq) › Levant › Syria > Oases and Steppe Dialects
Sedentary dialect with many influences of the surrounding bedouin-type dialects

Soukhne is a town located in the Syrian Steppe close to the eastern border of the province of Homs. The importance of the former caravan city increased throughout the centuries, when the town developed into a trade centre. Trade took place mostly between Bedouin tribes, for example the tribal confederation of ˁAnaza, and the local merchants. The town severely suffered from the civil war in Syria, particularly between 2015 and 2017 when it was under control of ISIS forces.

Soukhne is described as a town with a dynamic history. Local merchants used to travel to various Syrian regions, but also to Iraq and Turkey and therefore adopted different linguistic elements that contributed to the shaping of the dialect of Soukhne. Behnstedt 1994 describes the dialect as a mixture of bedouin and sedentary elements.

The first description of the dialect of this oasis is found in Cantineau 1956. The most comprehensive study on the dialect spoken in Soukhne is undoubtedly Behnstedt 1994. Consisting of three parts, this work includes a broad variety of ethnographic texts in Part 1 as well as an in-depth investigation of phonology, morphology and syntax in Part 2.
A comprehensive glossary is found in Behnstedt 1994, Part 3. It is based on the texts of Part 1 of the same book.
There are 113 audio-files of texts from Soukhne in SemArch - Semitisches Tonarchiv: http://www.semarch.uni-hd.de
To view a list of the important publications on this variety follow this link.

titleStmt.title: A machine-readable profile of Ahwaz/Ahvaz Arabic
titleStmt.author: Bettina Leitner

sourceDesc.p: This is an original digital text

div.p: East › Mesopotamia › Iraq › South Iraq
Bedouin-type gələt dialect; mixed variety with urban and rural features; strong Persian influence on the lexicon

Ahwāz is the capital city of the southwestern Iranian province of Khūzestān and situated alongside the river Kārūn. Of its 1.5 million inhabitants Arabs are the biggest ethnic group, the second biggest group are Persians. There is also a small group of Sabeans living in Aḥwāz.
The city was apparently flourishing in pre-Islamic times but declined in the subsequent centuries to a village of about 10,000 inhabitants in the early 20th century.
Today many of the city’s inhabitants are working in the sugar cane and oil industry.

With the discovery of oil in the vicinity of Aḥwāz (1908) and during the time of the Iran-Iraq war, in which Aḥwāz was considered one of province’s the safer cities, many Arab people from the surrounding areas have moved to the capital city. This resulted in the penetration of many rural features into the originally urban dialect of Aḥwāz and thus reshaped its linguistic profile.

The first written document on the dialect of Aḥwāz is an unpublished and undated manuscript by D. Lorimer, in which he collected mainly lexical lists and verbal conjugation patterns. Further linguistic information on the dialect of Aḥwāz and other villages and cities in Khūzestān was gathered by Bruce Ingham, who published two articles (1973, 1976) on regional differences within Khūzestān including short texts, and a short grammatical analysis in EALL (2007). Ingham (1991) is a short study on sentence structure in Khuzestan Arabic.
To view a list of the important publications on Iranian Arabic follow this link.

titleStmt.title: A machine-readable profile of Abu Dhabi Arabic
titleStmt.author: Stephanie

sourceDesc.p: This is an original digital text

div.p: East (Mashriq) > Arabia > Northern group > Central Najd > Gulf
Originally a bedouin-type dialect belonging to the ˁAnaza group; during the last decades in a state of transition

Abu Dhabi is the capital of the United Arab Emirates and its second largest city. Until the mid-20th century Abu Dhabi was a small town of less than 25,000 inhabitants, but has grown rapidly in the following decades reaching one million in the early 2000s. However, only a small proportion of its inhabitants are native speakers of the local Arabic dialect.
Johnstone (1967) presents an overview of the Eastern Arabian dialects in general, but also contains several pages devoted to the dialect of Abu Dhabi.

The sound change from /ǧ/ to /y/, which is typical for Gulf Arabic, is described in Johnstone 1965. Qafisheh 1977 is based on the dialect of Abu Dhabi and comprises in addition to phonology, morphology and syntax also texts.
The focus of Al-Rawi's study (1990) is on phonology and nominal morphology; it also contains a number of ethnographic texts. Some information on Abu Dhabi is also found in Holes 1990.

Based on the speech of Abu Dhabi, Qatar and Bahrain, Hamdi A. Qafisheh published three textbooks of Gulf Arabic. Qafisheh 1975 for beginners, Qafisheh 1979 and Qafisheh 1997 for advanced students. Another textbook is Holes 1984.
To view a list of the important publications on varieties spoken in the Gulf follow this link.

titleStmt.title: A machine-readable profile of Benghazi Arabic
titleStmt.author: Sherin

sourceDesc.p: This is an original digital text

div.p: West (Maghreb) > Libya > North Eastern Libya
Bedouin-type dialect
Benghazi is the most important city of the Cyrenaica region and Libyas’s second largest city. The Arabic dialect of Benghazi has an estimated half million speakers (Benkato 2014).

Important data about the dialect comes from the Italian scholar Ester Panetta, who published extensively on the spoken language of Benghazi: Her 2-volume monograph L’arabo parlato a Bengasi (1943) provides texts and describes the grammar of the Benghazi dialect. Between 1958 and 1980 she published phrases and words in a dictionary-like form including words beginning with the letters A, B, C, D and E in different journals and books.

The British linguist T.F. Mitchell dedicated two articles to the dialect of the Cyrenaica in which he also mentioned features of the dialect of Benghazi: The active participle in an Arabic Dialect of the Cyrenaica (1952) and The language of buying and selling in Cyrenaica (1957).

Jonathan Owens also contributed immensely to the knowledge about Benghazi dialect with his book A short reference grammar of Eastern Libyan Arabic (1984), in which he offers a full and detailed grammatical description of Eastern Libyan Arabic. In his 2001 and 2005 articles, Jacques Gand’Henry provides texts in transcription, translation, and a short linguistic analysis.

The most recent publications on Benghazi Arabic are by Adam Benkato (2014 and 2017) and Luca D’Anna (2016): The 2014 article by Benkato provides a historical overview of the region and describes the linguistic features of Benghazi Arabic, including changes between the early studies and his own observations during his fieldwork in 2010 and 2011.
An up-to-date annotated bibliography of Benghazi and Eastern Libyan dialects can be found in Benkato and Pereira 2016.
To view a list of important publications relevant to this variety follow this link.

titleStmt.title: A machine-readable profile of Tozeur Arabic
titleStmt.author: Marlene Holzmann

sourceDesc.p: This is an original digital text

div.p: West (Maghreb) > Tunisia > Southwestern Tunisia
Bedouin-type dialect with numerous elements from sedentary dialects

Tozeur as the capital of the Tozeur Governorate is located in South-western Tunisia. The oasis which is well known for its vast date palm groves and its typical clay brick architecture is situated north of the Chott el-Djerid. For centuries, the town was a main hub for caravans crossing the Sahara.

The dialect spoken in Tozeur is a transitional Bedouin-type dialect that shows features of both the Hilal- and Sulaym-type dialects, but also considerable influence of sedentary dialects. Hitherto little research has been done on the dialect of Tozeur. Information on phonology, morphology, and syntax is provided by Saada 1984; a corpus of mainly ethnographic texts was published by the same author in 1981.
Saada 1984 also contains a 30-page glossary.
To view publications on this variety follow this link.

titleStmt.title: A machine-readable profile of Taizz Arabic
titleStmt.author: Benjamin Suter

sourceDesc.p: This is an original digital text

div.p: East (Mashriq) › Arabia › Yemen › Western Highlands
Urban dialect of mixed character

Taizz is located on the crossings of several main roads connecting it directly with Sanaa in the north, Aden in the south, and Mocha at the Red Sea. Hence, the local vernacular is strongly exposed to influences from other Yemeni dialects. This makes it difficult to identify a genuine Taˁizzī dialect. Basically, it belongs to the “Western Highlands” dialect group whose hallmark is the so-called k-perfect – i.e. the conjugation of the perfect of the 1st singular and 2nd singular and plural with suffixes containing /k/ where Standard Arabic and other varieties have /t/ (e.g. katab-ku ‘I wrote’). This, however, is now mostly avoided by urban speakers in favour of the forms with a t and cannot be considered typical for Taˁizzī Arabic nowadays.

The dialect of Taizz has not yet been studied thoroughly. In Werner Diem’s Skizzen
jemenitischer
Dialekte (1973), a short description of some morphological features of Taˁizzī Arabic can be found, based on recordings from speakers living in Beirut (pp.102-109). Theodore Prochazka (1974) briefly discusses the use and the distribution of the k-perfect in the Arabic of Taizz.
Peter Behnstedt’s Dialect Atlas of North Yemen and Adjacent Areas (2017) allows for comparison of several lexical and grammatical features of Taˁizzī Arabic with other Yemeni dialects.
Some dialectal vocabulary related to Taizz is found in Peter Behnstedt’s Glossar (1992-2006).
To view publications on this variety follow this link.

titleStmt.title: A machine-readable profile of Tiberias Arabic
titleStmt.author: Karoline Köster

sourceDesc.p: This is an original digital text

div.p: East (Mashriq) › Levant › Palestine > Galilee
Urban, sedentary dialect of the biˀūl-type; in situ only spoken by Jews

Tiberias is a small town in lower Galilee at the shores of the Sea of Galilee, which in Arabic is named after the city Buḥayrat Ṭabariyya. It is both a touristic and economic centre of the region. Furthermore, the city plays an important role in Judaism and for a long time the large Jewish population lived side by side with the Muslim Arabs of that place. In 1948 the Arab population of Tiberias was driven out of the city, but there is a – albeit rapidly decreasing – number of Jews with Arabic as their mother tongue. The dialect therefore can be regarded as a highly endangered variety, because it will probably fade with the death of the current generation of its speakers.

A very detailed and substantial study on the Judeo-Arabic dialect of Tiberias was done by Geva-Kleinberger (2009), who examined the features of this dialect and especially its autochthonous phrases on the basis of numerous recorded and transcribed texts, mainly by elderly people who have kept their dialect over the decades. A preliminary study of this work with only one sample text is Geva-Kleinberger 2004. Even though already at the beginning of the 20th century the dialect area of Palestine has been examined, there is no dictionary or grammatical study on Tiberias. Nevertheless one can find some data in Bergsträsser’s Sprachatlas von Syrien und Palästina 1915 (location no. 36). He did not include transcribed texts of that, but from numerous maps, one can extract different dialectal features that were used by the (Muslim) speakers of Tiberias.
There is one audio-file with a text in the Jewish dialect in SemArch- Semitisches Tonarchiv: http://www.semarch.uni-hd.de.
To view publications on this variety follow this link.
